data.text:
In the sci-fi novel VALIS by Philip K Dick, Horselover Fat is an imaginary mirror-image constructed from main character Phil. Fat is depicted as mentally unstable, after he experiences repeated loss of his friend Gloria from suicide and then later on the death of his friend Sherri who passed away from cancer. Fat turns to religion in search of meaning because he believes that; “if this is the sequence, everything built up ends in death. Death hides within every religion.” (Dick 1968, 195)

Fat believes that he has been in contact with a higher power and he convinces Phil and Kevin on a journey to meet the “Messiah” after seeing a science fiction adaptation of futuristic higher intelligence systems making, who have made contact with human beings named: “VALIS” (Vast Active Living Intelligence System). She is the messenger of Wisdom, the opposite of humanity’s “Will to Power.” She is here to transmit wisdom upon those who follow her, and she imposes the notion that Phil, Fat and Kevin should embrace her wisdom and let go of human power to achieve an ultimate form of purpose. Sophia represent the Messiah of a new image, she is the same, the mirror image of child, who life will repeat itself in transition from life to death. However, her purpose is to spread the ideology that the importance is: “What you teach is the word of man. Man is holy, and the true god, the living god, is man himself. You will have no gods but yourselves; the days in which you believed in other gods end now, they end forever. (Dick 1968, 219) Sophia tells them to find meaning within themselves, that the purpose to life does not lie upon the dealings an all divine God, that created human beings in his image.
